Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: A morphometric assessment of Chinese Lystrosaurus species

ProgramReference.Text: US CHINA COOP IN BASIC SCIENCE

POR.DRECONTENT:
About 250 million years ago, across the Permian-Triassic (P-T) boundary, the world experienced the largest mass extinction it has ever undergone, with most life on Earth dying out. One animal that survived was Lystrosaurus, a two-tusked, dog-sized herbivore very distantly related to mammals. It thrived in its environment, becoming the most abundant terrestrial vertebrate in Early Triassic beds across the world. The exact nature of the P-T extinction is unknown, and knowing why Lystrosaurus survived may help to understand it better.

One possibility is that it inhabited an advantageous morphospace- a range of shape variation- which allowed it to survive the extinction event. To assess this possibility, shape variation in Lystrosaurus skulls were examined using a set of techniques called geometric morphometrics. These methods employ homologous landmarks- features which are undeniably the same from species to species. The bending of shape space between landmarks is analyzed, making the data comprehensive and independent. Size is also factored out, leaving shape as the only feature being examined. These traits make geometric morphometrics much more precise than previous methods of shape analysis, such as taking linear measurements.

An examination of this nature has not previously been undertaken because the number of species known is uncertain. The genus has been over-split, though much work has been done on Lystrosaurus from the southern continents, and their taxonomy is nearly stabilized. The species in China had not yet been examined in detail until this study. This study does so as a step toward the larger goal of examining extinction survivorship.

The results of these analyses suggest that some species in China are invalid. Differences in the shape of key bones and bony ornamentation between Chinese and southern species also suggest that they are distinct from each other.

The P-T mass extinction was a global phenomenon which occurred while all the continents were connected as the supercontinent Pangaea. Understanding its causes will require multiple lines of evidence from across the world. Lystrosaurus from the southern continents were analyzed in the same manner prior to this study. By applying the same methods to Lystrosaurus from both southern and northern Pangaea, local phenomena can be filtered out in favor of global phenomena. This study crosses international borders, fostering cooperation between workers in China and those studying the southern continents.

The results of this study will be presented at the 2011 Society of Vertebrate Paleontology meeting, with several peer-reviewed papers to follow on the Chinese species and combined datasets with southern species.
